circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery:
Human skull with maxilla and mandible obtained by the Lewis and Clark County Office of the Coroner in 1996.  Unknown origin.

Two teeth were tested for radiocarbon at the University of Arizona Accelerator Mass Spectrometry Laboratory.  According to these reports, Dr. Greg Hodgins determined that there was no evidence of bomb carbon in these teeth, which means it’s unlikely the individual lived after 1955.

circumstances.circumstancesOfRecovery: The frontal portion of a partial human skull was found on an island in the Clark Fork River near the Turah Fishing Access by a crew spraying for invasive weeds. The area is prone to heavy spring flooding; after extensive searching with cadaver dogs, no other human remains were found. Forensic analysis of the skull fragment indicates the decedent to be a small-statured adult, most likely male, of an unknown age and ethnic heritage. The condition of the skull suggests that it had been skeletonized for several years at a minimum. There was no trauma.
